events.title: Birth
events.summary: Anton Webern was born in Vienna, Austria-Hungary, as the only surviving son of Carl von Webern, a member of minor nobility and a high-ranking civil servant. His mother, Amalie, an accomplished pianist and singer, played a significant role in his musical upbringing. He spent much of his early youth in Graz and Klagenfurt, where he was introduced to various instruments by his family, which nurtured his passion for music.
events.fun_version: Anton Webern, the only surviving son of Carl von Webern, a nobleman and high-ranking civil servant, was born in opulent Vienna, Austria-Hungary. His mother, Amalie, an accomplished pianist and singer, played a significant role in his musical upbringing. Growing up in Graz and Klagenfurt, he had so many instruments around him, it was like a musical buffet—‘I'll take a little of that cello, and a big slice of piano, please!’

events.title: Early Musical Education
events.summary: From an early age, Webern received music education from his mother. He learned to play several instruments including drums, trumpet, and violin, and was taught cello by Edwin Komauer. The family frequently engaged in playing chamber music together, exposing Webern to the works of great composers like Mozart, Schubert, and Beethoven, which had a lasting impact on his musical career.
events.fun_version: Webern's early music education was a 'drum roll please!' moment. His mother, the real MVP, started him on a path to musical greatness, giving him lessons so he could eventually become a one-man band! He learned to juggle drums, trumpet, and violin, and let’s not forget his cello tutor, Edwin Komauer, who probably deserved a medal for bravery for teaching a kid who could already play three instruments. The family frequently engaged in playing chamber music together, exposing Webern to the works of great composers like Mozart, Schubert, and Beethoven. Those gatherings led to Webern becoming a pioneer in modern music.

events.title: University Studies
events.summary: Webern studied musicology at the University of Vienna from 1902 to 1906 under Guido Adler. His education was complemented by studies in art history and philosophy. He was deeply engaged in analyzing Beethoven's quartets, which significantly influenced his compositional style. He completed his doctoral thesis on the historical development of musical styles.
events.fun_version: Webern went to the University of Vienna, where he jammed out at musicology from 1902 to 1906, under the legendary maestro Guido Adler. You could say his studies in art history and philosophy were the perfect side gigs! While everyone else was busy dancing to Beethoven’s hits, Webern took a deep dive into Beethoven's quartets, which significantly influenced his compositional style, like they were the secret menu at a fancy restaurant. He even wrote a doctoral thesis on the historical development of musical styles—because who doesn’t love history and music sandwiches?

events.title: Early Conducting Career
events.summary: Webern began conducting and coaching singers and choirs, gaining experience in the operetta and light music scenes. Although he had mixed feelings about this genre, he eventually found appreciation for certain works, indicating an evolving perspective on his craft during this period.
events.fun_version: Webern began conducting choirs and thought he could make light music, as if he was the Mozart of karaoke night! At first, he was confused like a cat in a dog show, but after a few performances, he started to tap his feet and say, 'Hey, this isn't just light; it's as bright as a disco ball at a wedding!' Eventually, he found appreciation for certain works, indicating that his perspective on his craft was evolving.

events.title: Marriage
events.summary: In 1911, Webern married his cousin Wilhelmine "Minna" Mörtl in a civil ceremony. Their marriage followed an earlier pregnancy, leading to a religious solemnization of their union in 1915 after the birth of three children. Their relationship was marked by a shared love for literature and nature, often reflected in Webern's writings.
events.fun_version: In 1911, Webern married his cousin Wilhelmine 'Minna' Mört in a civil ceremony, which means they filled out some paperwork together. Their marriage came after an earlier little surprise led to a proper wedding in 1915 — apparently, three kids will motivate you to get serious. Their relationship was marked by a shared love for literature and nature, and they enjoyed bonding over books and outdoor escapades, proving that shared interests are key to a happy marriage!

events.title: Post-War Activities
events.summary: After World War I, Webern actively participated in the Society for Private Musical Performances, promoting new music and collaborating with contemporaries. This period marked his rise as an important figure in the avant-garde music scene, advocating for contemporary composers.
events.fun_version: In the wake of World War I, Webern joined the Society for Private Musical Performances, promoting new music and collaborating with contemporaries. He contributed significantly to the new music movement during this period, marking his emergence as a key figure in the avant-garde music scene and actively advocating for contemporary composers.

events.title: World War I Service
events.summary: During World War I, Webern served intermittently in the military, reflecting a sense of patriotism despite the toll it took on him personally and professionally. After the war ended, he sought to return to composing more seriously, which was restricted due to his military obligations.
events.fun_version: During World War I, Webern served intermittently in the military, reflecting a sense of patriotism despite the toll it took on him personally and professionally. He was trying to juggle his passion for composing with a serious case of patriotism! After the war, he sought to return to composing more seriously, but more military obligations came knocking at his door.

events.title: Death
events.summary: Anton Webern was tragically killed by a US soldier in an accident in Mittersill, Austria, shortly after the end of World War II. His unexpected death left a profound impact on the music world, highlighting the tumultuous events surrounding the war and its aftermath.
events.fun_version: Anton Webern, a composer, was dedicated to his music. His concert was cut short in Mittersill, Austria, shortly after World War II, by an accident involving a US soldier. His abrupt departure left the music world feeling a profound impact, underlining the tumultuous events surrounding the war and its aftermath.

3 Lieder für Sopran, Klarinette und Gitarre, Op.18
